content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will happen in about 1h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

We will have checkins from:

  • @WG-rls2.0 by @matklad
  • @WG-self-profile by @Wesley Wiser
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , triage is starting now! Add a :wave: to show you're here!

We'll start off with five minutes for

Announcements
• The #t-compiler/shrinkmem-sprint is progressing. :)

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "Filter out query machinery from compiler backtraces by default"

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Debuggable Macro Expansions" compiler-team#386
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Staged queries" compiler-team#391
    • "Do not traverse the HIR to generate metadata" compiler-team#392
    • "Embed version numbers in backport nominations and regression labels" compiler-team#393
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403

Several of us are hanging out in a video/voice chat room for the memshrink-sprint. Stop by and say hello if you're interested!
https://meet.jit.si/853369840823083

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Adding diesel to the cargotest suite" rust#81507
    • "add dynamically-linked musl targets" rust#82556

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Eagerly construct bodies of THIR" compiler-team#409

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Tracking Issue for ASCII methods on OsStr" rust#70516
    • "Tracking Issue for str_split_once" rust#74773
    • "Lint for unused borrows as part of UNUSED_MUST_USE" rust#76894
    • "[librustdoc] Only split lang string on ,, , and \t" rust#78429
    • "Stabilize unsafe_op_in_unsafe_fn lint" rust#79208
    • "Make rustdoc lints a tool lint instead of built-in" rust#80527

"Make rustdoc lints a tool lint instead of built-in" rust#80527

this was merged just today!
• crater run for beta 1.51 (https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/milestone/79) does not identify any T-compiler breakage in need of fixing, so looks like this release should hopefully be pretty smooth

"[librustdoc] Only split lang string on ,, , and \t" rust#78429

and this was merged last week :)
We have no steering meeting tomorrow (Friday).
However, we do have a planning meeting a week from tomorrow, March 12th.
we're looking for proposals for meetings, see how to do it here

(we don't really have any meeting proposals currently, apart from a regression day, which from @simulacrum 's message above, I'm thinking we will not need a Friday meeting for that. I need to go clean up the current (old) set of proposals.)
WG checkins

@WG-rls2.0 by @matklad
We've finished our first 6 weeks "sprint" (tracking issue) with mixed results

  • rust-analyzer now supprts items declared inside function bodies
  • we are preparing to enable proc-macro suport by default. In particular, rust-analyzer suppors asynchronous execution of build scripts and loading of proc-macro.
  • we've switched macro-by-example parser to use a proper NFA, getting closer to parity with rustc at the cost of 2x worser expansion performance :(
  • "new mutable immutable syntax trees" work is still not finished, but it has progressed enough to rewrite one assist to confirm that the new API works and is significantly more ergonomic.
/me is curious about how well a 6-week sprint works vs 1-week sprint. :wink:

@WG-self-profile by @Wesley Wiser:

  • We released measureme@9.1 last week :tada: (release notes)
    • The biggest feature is @eddyb's support for hardware performance counters
    • We've updated rustc to use the new version
    • This has unblocked @eddyb's PR to use hardware performance counters for -Zself-profile
Backport nominations
T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

• "Fix popping singleton paths in when generating E0433" rust#82259
    • opened by osa1
    • fixes #82156, a P-medium ICE instead of emitting a syntax error when calling super()
    • approved by @Vadim Petrochenkov
This is a small fix, though the offending code wouldn't compile either way, so no super strong feelings about the :back:
Yeah this seems like something we should backport, since if I understand correctly, no diagnostic is issued, we just ICE. :sad:

is curious about how well a 6-week sprint works vs 1-week sprint. :wink:

@pnkfelix to clarify, we still release every week, we use 6week chunks to organize bigger chunks of works. So that the changelog is not just "various fixes and improvements"
(though I also think the diagnostic it currently issues is non-ideal: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82259/files#diff-00a06df477930ecba8dfc492d2fadbb8a2a793376ec79a942d95c08aac8baf51 )

@matklad that is actually pretty amazing: You release every week, while rustc releases every 6-weeks. But then you have a 6-week long sprint, while we are hobbling together a 1-week sprint. :laughing:
anyway, beta backport approved for #82259

• "Fix popping singleton paths in when generating E0433" rust#82259
    • see above: safe for stable backport?
I ... think we can live without stably backporting this...?
Sure, its probably low risk, but I suspect its lower value.
from time to time I may be more conservative but yeah we can also live without the beta backporting :)
note that I voted to backport to beta and stable :P
(@Jonas Schievink [he/him] added the stable nomination, might have more info about #82259)
@Santiago Pastorino sure, the same argument could be applied to the beta backport.
yeah, unsure if we have some kind of guidance, policy
anyway something to discuss on a separate topic
I was assuming @Jonas Schievink [he/him] added the stable nomination just because it was identified as a stable regression
yeah
@Santiago Pastorino to me, the difference between stable vs beta here is that we'll have some amount of time to see this bake, and thus revert the beta backport if necessary
(I cannot imagine needing to do so, but :shrug: )
anyway, I don't think anyone besides @Santiago Pastorino has voted for :back: . So I'm going to decline to stable-backport
If someone wants to argue more strongly for backport, feel free to speak up (either via privmsg or at the end of the meeting.)

• "libtest: Fix unwrap panic on duplicate TestDesc" rust#82274
    • opened by @Anders Kaseorg
    • approved by @simulacrum, raises a question about this patch that is addressed in the follow-up PR #82300
no unit test on the PR
is this something we cannot readily unit test?
I think it's not impossible, not sure what kind of tests we have today
I can ask for a unit test in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82300
so what happens in this code now when the if let Some(running_test) = .. goes into the non-existent else case here?
we issue a single event notification, when two might have been expected?
or, no: I guess we still issue two? And we still decrement pending twice?
/me thinks
FWIW I think this could also be considered a rustdoc bug, in that generating identical TestDescs seems bad
I think this patch is not intending to really fix, more patch over and prevent the panic
okay
I'm willing to go along with that
beta backport approved.

• "Revert LLVM D81803 because it broke Windows 7" rust#82605
    • opened by @cuviper
    • approved by @Nikita Popov
    • fix a critical issue #82605 blocking build any archives on Windows 7 (issue #81051)
(sorry! I got distracted by reading and forgot to add the emoji votes)

fix a critical issue #82605

(sorry for the typo, the link is for ther pr)
yeah I think this is clear beta backport approved

T-libs-impl stable / T-libs-impl beta

  • "[beta] Fix TcpListener::accept() on x86 Android on beta by disabling the use of accept4." rust#82476
(do we still handle these, or does the libs-impl team now meet regularly enough to handle it?)
@Mara ^ ?
(Might be worth having a meeting about this question)
btw, note that this wasn't yet merged to master but it's already r+ed
@pnkfelix T-libs-impl hasn't started yet. should happen Soon™ though!
also, this is a stable-to-stable regression, so in theory it could be nominated for beta-backport stable-backport
Okay, thanks @Mara ! We'll keep handling these in the meantime then!
You mean stable backport?

Wesley Wiser said:

You mean stable backport?

oh jeez
anyway
lets just resolve the beta backport Q here for now
Looks amazingly low risk to me. :)
(I suppose one might argue that the SYS_accept4 branch should be cfg'ed with an allowlist rather than a denylist.)
(cc @Maarten de Vries, since these are your PRs ^)
(but I'm not going to make that argument beyond that note.)
beta backport approved.

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

• "reduce threads spawned by ui-tests" rust#81942
    • opened by @The 8472 (@The 8472?)
    • @simulacrum raises concerns about maintaining the complexity cost, suggests more eyeballs on this PR
    • @nagisa raise a concern that this could break tests sensible to the absence of a -Ccodegen-units flag
    • CI seems to not pass consistently
(was I supposed to do something here?)
I recall something
in any case, I don't think it needs further team discussion, but I'm still feeling uncertain tbh :)
It reports a nice drop in wallclock time
(@pnkfelix @Wesley Wiser and yes, let's have a meeting when T-libs-impl kicks off to talk about the things we should handle that t-compiler has been doing.)
like a 7 second reduction in wallclock time, for a 50-60 second task
I do wonder about the CI issues
namely this: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/81942/commits/4b3adcf38f28f60e10d83464a59d869ab13460b3#r579812377
Faster but flaky tests sounds like a bad tradeoff :grimacing:
the problem is that I don't know if this PR is making the tests more flaky
or just exposing existing flakiness
I think it's likely to introduce even more system-specific behavior, which worries me
but most of my fears are sort of non-concrete
I think I asked last week about the lld stuff
in terms of how much of the benefit here is tied to that
I dunno. I guess I'm inclined to go ahead and land it.
but I do see @Esteban Küber 's point about flaky test. I've lost a lot of engineering hours to such.
Lets go with a vote. :+1: on this if you think we should go ahead and land this. :-1: if you think we should close it without landing it due to aforementioned concerns.
(but I'd say my -1 is sort of -0)
(i added a :shrug: for people who want to express their desire to not vote in either direction.)
wow even the :shrug: doesn't get any love? Does Zulip need a :bell: notification or something?
I'm very wary of even jokingly invoking @ here
but it's very tempting
I would vote against landing if there's concern that we're going to make our test suite flaky(er?). But if that concern was resolved, I'd have no issue landing.
okay well now we need to decide whether to just leave this open for another week, or to use some other (asynchronous) system for making decision here, like an FCP
I'll go ahead and FCP merge on it.
then people can register concerns that way
so I guess that was a mis-use of meeting time

• "add dynamically-linked musl targets" rust#82556
    • opened by @Ariadne Conill
    • assigned to @nagisa, raises some concerns on the behaviour consistency
    • assigned also to @Vadim Petrochenkov, provides a great summary on Zulip, suggests to enable dynamic linking on nightly to see what breaks
    • @richfelker (author and mantainer of musl) recommends proper naming to avoid confusion
    • discussion is still ongoing, revolves around clarifying the --target behaviour and what people expect when compiling for MUSL
I don't think we can meaningfully discuss this in today's meeting
I'm curious whether it might deserve a Friday meeting slot.
Does the fcp need to be canceled? The discussion seems to have evolved significantly since it was started.
Although, I guess most people haven't signed off yet.

Wesley Wiser said:

Does the fcp need to be canceled? The discussion seems to have evolved significantly since it was started.

where?
on #82556? I don't see an FCP there.
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82556#issuecomment-787079067
It's uh buried in the hidden comment section.
oh ARGH github you and your hidden comment!
what is point of search in a browser if ... GAAAAH
good thing Oli has me muted in the jitsi
Lol
hmm. Given that this has an FCP filed, now I don't know what to think in terms of whether to suggest a friday meeting
anyway, I think we should move along right now
I mean I guess to my point, once discussion has died out, perhaps we should restart the fcp.
in terms of #82556: @nagisa , maybe review the discussion and see if you think things have changed significantly as to warrant a cancel and restart of the FCP

T-libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on T-libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 65 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 40 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 1 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 1 P-critical, 39 P-high, 86 P-medium, 10 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • No P-critical issues for T-compiler this time.
We're low on time so I'm going to skip the T-libs-impl bugs (and the empty list of rustdoc bugs)

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • No P-high beta regressions this time.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

Triage full logs

Quiet week, a couple regressions and several nice improvements.

Triage done by @simulacrum.

2 Regressions, 3 Improvements, 0 Mixed, 0 of them in rollups

Regressions

Use correct param_env in conservative_is_privately_uninhabited #82159

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 1.2% on incr-unchanged builds of regression-31157-opt)
  • Seems like a necessary bugfix.

Detect match statement intended to be tail expression #81458

  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 5.6% on incr-patched: println builds of unicode_normalization-check)
  • Unexpected regresssion, left nag.

Improvements

  • Prevent to compute Item attributes twice #82265
  • Miscellaneous inlining improvements #82559
  • Remove storage markers if they won't be used during code generation #78360

Nags requiring follow up

Detect match statement intended to be tail expression #81458

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/81458#issuecomment-789003548

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

• "fn() -> Out is a valid type for unsized types Out, and it implements FnOnce<(), Output = Out>" rust#82633
    • opened by @Frank Steffahn
    • issue bisection seems to point to PR #73905
    • issue seems to reproducible on stable since long (so not a regression) but to be unsound on nightly
    • something to investigate a bit closer
hmm
I thnk we @WG-prioritization were a bit confused (at least I was)
well we are out of time

apiraino said:

I thnk we @WG-prioritization were a bit confused (at least I was)

about which?
the implication and priority for #82633
oh, like whether it is P-high or P-critical ?
it needs #![feature(unboxed_closures)] to be exploited, as far as we know
so P-high sounds okay to me.
but I think it does need an owner.
oh, let me read comments more carefully
namely the one from @Frank Steffahn about such types still being observable on stable ...
Lets leasve it at P-high for now
but also leave it nominated so that it comes up again at next meeting. Unless it gets an owner in the meantime. I'll leave a comment to that effect.

Before people leave, @Wesley Wiser @pnkfelix I want to make sure we don't let the musl issue fall through. The porter has been expressing a lot of frustration with the tooling and preemptive fears of being gate kept. They seem interested in arriving to a solution that is amenable to both us and the distros. Let's not have an unnecessary breakdown of communication by accident.
Yes, agreed! I'm very happy to see this work happening.
Yes I did see them expressing concern at various points, especially in their reactions to some of the emoji’s that were tagged on it
I’m still interested in whether there might be something Friday meeting worthy here
potentially independently of that PR
I probably should read the dialogue on that PR carefully and figure out what kind of Friday meeting I might like to have
It sounds like we could have a meeting about the feasibility of changing what the -musl targets mean. Which was one direction the conversation had gone last I read.
So, just to cap things off: Thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending
I'm pretty sure we still need some discussion/consensus in T-compiler on what to do wrt musl. I'm happy to look at cutting out an hour of my calendar to dedicate for this on friday.
can you ping me on that? i can get rich in here to help make our case

Draft for next week's agenda:
https://hackmd.io/3dTKNk1_RiK3NOZMfyOldw?view

Scheduled checkins:

  • @WG-async-foundations by @nikomatsakis and @tmandry
  • @WG-traits by @nikomatsakis and @Jack Huey

Ariadne Conill said:

can you ping me on that? i can get rich in here to help make our case

it will be in https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings, usually someone posts a placeholder message about an hour before
well, it hasn't been scheduled yet...

nagisa said:

I'm pretty sure we still need some discussion/consensus in T-compiler on what to do wrt musl. I'm happy to look at cutting out an hour of my calendar to dedicate for this on friday.

Okay. Lets try to make sure this is one of the items we propose at next week’s planning meeting.
